pullRequest.body:
The fourth PR in [this series](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/144837-PR-reviews/topic/Prerequisites.20for.20PNT.20and.20Dirichlet's.20Thm/near/482005581) extends the LSeries API by showing that forming the LSeries commutes with finite sums.

From [EulerProducts](https://github.com/MichaelStollBayreuth/EulerProducts).

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [2d7b1a7dc3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18928/commits/2d7b1a7dc384b9dbf31ba02addc21f30e1b0e4aa)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ LSeries.term_sum`
`+ LSeries.term_sum_apply`
`+ LSeriesHasSum.sum`
`+ LSeriesSummable.sum`
`+ LSeries_sum`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

LGTM now, just needs a simp flag

maintainer delegate

LGTM now, just needs a simp flag

maintainer delegate
wouldn't it be simpler to do cases on `n` here rather than induction on `S`?
I think `Fintype.sum` doesn't actually exist, and `âˆ‘ i : Î¹, f i` is just syntactic sugar for `âˆ‘ i âˆˆ univ, f i`. So I am not sure what these additional lemmas are needed for.

There are quite a few lemmas called `Fintype.sum_<blah>`, so there is precedent. But you are right that `Fintype.sum` as such does not exist. So the question is perhaps if the existence of the other `Fintype.sum_<blah>` lemmas justifies having these variants here, too. (The docstrings need to be changed, of course.)
(At the one point where I'm using the `Fintype` variant later, I can of course easily switch to the unprimed version at the cost of adding a `_`, so I'm open to removing these.)

I recall this discussion came up on another PR recently â€“Â I can't remember if that was one of yours or someone else's â€“ and we agreed that there is only a need for a `Fintype.sum_xxx` variant when the fintype statement was genuinely different from, and simpler than, the corresponding `Finset` statement applied to `univ`, as with `Fintype.prod_sum` compared to `Finset.prod_sum`. By your last message it sounds like that isn't the case here.
OK; then I'll just delete these three lemmas.
It doesn't hurt, and follows the precedent of `Finset.sum_apply`.

pullRequest.title: feat: LSeries commutes with finite sums
